name: Sinhagad Fort
description: Sinhagad Fort is a historic hill fortress located 30 km southwest of Pune. Famous for the Battle of Sinhagad in 1670, where Tanaji Malusare sacrificed his life to capture it from the Mughals. The fort offers panoramic views, easy trekking routes, and authentic Maharashtrian food.

routes.name: Donje Village Route
routes.description: Well-maintained stone steps from Donje village to fort top. Most popular and easiest route suitable for beginners and families. 400 steps with railings.

routes.name: Ghorawadi Village Route
routes.description: Steeper and more rugged route. Less crowded, more scenic. Rocky terrain suitable for experienced trekkers.

routes.name: Motorable Road
routes.description: Vehicles can go up to parking area near fort. Shared jeeps available for ₹20-30 per person.

landmarks.name: Tanaji Malusare Memorial
landmarks.description: Memorial dedicated to Tanaji Malusare, the Maratha warrior who sacrificed his life capturing this fort in 1670. Features statue and historical inscriptions.
landmarks.historicalSignificance: Site commemorating the famous Battle of Sinhagad and Tanaji's sacrifice - 'Gad ala, pan Sinha gela' (Fort captured, but the lion is gone)

landmarks.name: Kaundinyeshwar Temple
landmarks.description: Ancient Shiva temple with traditional stone architecture. Peaceful atmosphere with priest sharing historical stories.
landmarks.historicalSignificance: Temple visited by Shivaji Maharaj. Important religious site on the fort.

landmarks.name: Rajaram's Tomb
landmarks.description: Tomb of Chhatrapati Rajaram Maharaj (son of Shivaji Maharaj). Maratha-era architecture with dome structure.
landmarks.historicalSignificance: Final resting place of Rajaram Maharaj who ruled after Shivaji

landmarks.name: Kalyan Darwaja
landmarks.description: Eastern gate of the fort with steep approach. Strategic entrance with excellent views. Requires careful climbing.
landmarks.historicalSignificance: One of the main defensive gates of the fort

landmarks.name: Pune Darwaja
landmarks.description: Main entrance gate facing Pune city. First landmark visitors see when arriving at fort top.
landmarks.historicalSignificance: Primary entrance to the fort, well-preserved structure

landmarks.name: Fort Walls and Ramparts
landmarks.description: Extensive fort walls offering 360-degree panoramic views of Pune city, Khadakwasla Dam, and surrounding Sahyadri mountains. Best photography spot.

landmarks.name: Military Stables
landmarks.description: Ruins of ancient horse stables and ammunition storage areas. Provides insight into fort's military operations.
landmarks.historicalSignificance: Shows military infrastructure of Maratha Empire

landmarks.name: Kali Temple
landmarks.description: Smaller temple dedicated to Goddess Kali. Less crowded, peaceful spot.

onFort.name: Pithla Bhakri
onFort.description: Gram flour curry served with thick millet bread. Authentic Maharashtrian village food. Served with raw onions and green chili.
onFort.vendor: Multiple stalls on fort top, Hotel Kondaji

onFort.name: Kanda Bhaji
onFort.description: Crispy onion fritters (pakoras). Best enjoyed hot with cutting chai.

onFort.name: Zunka Bhakar
onFort.description: Dry gram flour preparation with bhakri bread. Spicy and filling.

onFort.name: Fresh Dahi (Yogurt)
onFort.description: Homemade yogurt served in earthen pots. Incredibly creamy and fresh.

onFort.name: Cutting Chai
onFort.description: Half cup of strong, sweet tea. Perfect with bhaji.

onFort.name: Kokum Sherbet
onFort.description: Refreshing drink made from kokum fruit. Cooling and digestive.

onFort.name: Fresh Sugarcane Juice
onFort.description: Freshly extracted sugarcane juice. Very refreshing after trek.

onFort.name: Kavath (Wild Berries)
onFort.description: Seasonal wild berries available during monsoon. Local delicacy.

onFort.name: Vada Pav
onFort.description: Potato fritter in bread bun. Mumbai's famous street food available here too.

firstAid.location: Primary Health Center at Donaje village (3 km from fort)

alerts.message: Steep sections near Kalyan Darwaja - use railings carefully
Paths can be slippery during monsoon - wear proper footwear with grip
Fort walls don't have railings everywhere - be careful near edges, especially with kids
Leeches possible during monsoon - carry salt
Start descent by 4:30 PM to avoid darkness on trail

accessibility.alternativeAccess: Vehicles can go up to parking area. Shared jeeps available from base (₹20-30). Still requires 500m walk from parking to fort entrance.

visitInfo.bestTimeOfDay: Early morning (6-9 AM) for sunrise and cooler weather

topPositives: Easy trek suitable for beginners and families
Good for elderly with moderate fitness
topComplaints: Very crowded on weekends and holidays
reviewsSummary.bestQuote: Sinhagad is not just a trek, it's an experience. You feel the history, taste the culture, and witness nature's beauty. A must-visit for every Punekar!
tips: Visit on weekdays to avoid crowds
Start early (6 AM) for sunrise and cooler weather
Wear proper trekking shoes, NOT sandals
Carry 2 liters of water per person
Try the Pithla Bhakri - it's worth the trek alone
Don't rush the descent - most injuries happen going down
Monsoon is magical but paths are slippery
Carry cash - most vendors don't accept cards
Download offline maps - network can be patchy at top
Respect the fort - don't litter or damage structures

history.brief: Sinhagad (Lion's Fort) was previously called Kondhana. It has been the site of many important battles, most notably the Battle of Sinhagad in 1670 where Tanaji Malusare recaptured it from the Mughals.
history.significance: The fort represents Maratha valor and sacrifice. Tanaji's famous last words 'Gad ala, pan Sinha gela' (Fort captured, but the lion is gone) symbolize the price of freedom.
famousBattles: Battle of Sinhagad (1670) - Tanaji Malusare vs Udaybhan Rathod
